Posts.Content: I have a cyst as well.  The ultrasound revealed the cyst as being liquid (just a black spot on the screen).  If your breasts are prone to cysts, the one filled with liquid is far less harmful than a solid mass (shows as white or gray on the screen).  Don't panic but do follow up.  You need to be pro-active when it comes to you health issues.  If you don't like the Q and A session with your doctor, seek another one (God knows there are loads of doctors in this world).  You have to be persistant, assertive and inquisitive. This can directly affect you and and your well being. Doctors often think of their patients as naive, lacking medical knowledge etc and therefor hate when asked a poignant questions - prove them wrong.
Posts.Title: Cyst left breast - cause for concern

Posts.Content: While I have never found a lump on my breast, I do have a very dense breast tissue, meaning that such tissue can hide evidence of cancer without revealing the signs on the memmogram.  In this case you should seek a CT scan and/or MRI to further assure yourself of lack of evidence of cancer. There are many articles and studies written on the subject of dense breast tissue.  Good luck,   Aranka
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: I just lost my friend.  She passed away on Saturday, February 11, 2012.  I truly did think that she would be able to beat this bloody cancer.  She was a nice person, full of life and energy. Her interests were broad, she loved to read, to laugh (I can still hear her laughter in my heart).  I am sad about her passing and while I know that I will never see her again, I am glad that her laughter will remain in my heart.  RIP dear Katja and I will always think of you, thank you for leaving your laughter behind.   Aranka
Posts.Title: Stage IV Breast Cancer - my friend

Posts.Content: I just had the memmogram done and have been told that my breasts's tissue is rather dense.  My doctor suggested the ultrasound.  I had the ultrasound and it appears that all is well. The techician who had administered the ultrasound suggested I do the MRI if ultrasound not effective.  She also told me that at times doctors perform biopsies just to make sure that growth is not cancerous.  Please follow up on this further and let me know the results.  I'll be thinking of you.   Aranka
Posts.Title: Did anyone's cancer NOT show up on Mammogram or Ultrasound?

Posts.Content: My very close friend (childhood friend) was treated for breast cancer several years ago. She lives in Geneva, Switzerland. Just recently she has been diagnozed with metastatic breast cancer. It appears that she has developed a secondary spot on her spine.  Her lymph notes are not involved.  She has undergone both radiation and chemo and to my great sadness her condition has not improved all that much.  She has been and I believe still is treated for severe bone pain, but her pain is not subsiding.  She has to sleep in a special bed and is currently taking cortisone to help her with the "overall bone ache throughout her body" (at least that is how she describes the pain).  I am very concerned for her.  This illness is making her suffer and it is so unfair. She is a great person and despite everything she is going through, she maintains her optimism and hope.  My question is:  what can we, her friends and family, expect in the future and how hopeful can we be about her life expectancy.  I am hoping against hope that her condition will improve, that this is just a temporary set-back.  Her sister is beyond herself with worry and I am just trying to find enough information about her condition.  I know that each case has to be treated separately, but an overall information would be so helful.   Many thanks,   Aranka
Posts.Title: Metastatic breas cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Teresa, many thanks for your optimistic message.  I will be thinking of your sister at the same time I am thinking of my friend Katja.  She is still in the hospital and for some odd reason they are not discharging her as of yet, which in itself is peculiar and subject to worry.  Her spirits are up from what I hear and she is at the moment refusing to discuss her illness. She is slated to go to a spcial rehab center (which of course is a private establisment and quite expensive and being in Geneve/Switzerland, you can only imagine how expensive it must be.  It is sad, actually repugnant how money has taken control over our lives. Living with a little bit of dignity is not much to ask for. Again, many thanks Teresa and the best to your sister.  If it is not much of an inconvenience, would you kindly advise me of any new treatment, news, anything that has to do with this bloody metastatic breast cancer.   God Bless,   Aranka
Posts.Title: Metastatic breas cancer

Posts.Content: Go to your Mom and be with her.  Be with her as much as you can.  To hell with the friends who do not understand what you are going through.  Your mom is the most important person at this moment.  Take many pictures of her as well .  I wish I could console you more but do know my thoughts are with you.  Many people on this site do care very much, so know that you are not alone, you have many, many friends who will be thinking of you in your moment of need.  Maybe you should ask you mom's doctor to explain to you just exactly what is going on.    I wish you the best and again, you are not alone, A
Posts.Title: My Mum Has Terminal Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Oh my God, my dearest friend who lives in Switzerland is in a similar situation.  Mets to bone is a very serious situation. My friend's cancer has now spread to her lungs.  She is in a hospice.  Dear God, there is no use in pretending that cancer is here to stay for a few months and it will disappear.  Be brave and spend as much time with your sister as you can.  My thoughts are with you as it appears that we both have loved ones in a similar situation. It is serious.  I am not saying that in your sister's case it is a beginnin of the end, but do accept the fact that it is serious and by spending time with her, you will cherish sweet moments with her for that much longer.  One day she will appear in your dream as real as real can be, you will touch her face and she will smile, I know it, I just know it.   Love,   Aranka
Posts.Title: My Sister, should I be concerned?

Posts.Content: Hi, of course it is worth the fight.  You have to stand up to cancer. Don't let it control your life.  Besides, every person is different and we all heel and respond to medication differently. If you don't fight, you will never know what you might have missed.  By fighting, you will gain far more than loose.  Don't listen to negative comments.  Our positive outlook on life is at times the best medicine.  I wish you lots of luck, strength and stamina in the days to come.  Please keep me posted.  I will be thinking of you. Aranka
Posts.Title: stage 4 triple positive breast cancer

Posts.Content: Get a second opinion, by all means.  You can google the fibroadenomas and learn more about it.  When you go for a second opinion, ask the doctor to submit you to MRI.  There are also  times doctor will perform the biopsy just to make sure that growth is not malignant.  Do everything possible to completely rule out possibility of malignant tumors.   Wishing you the best of luck, get goint on this immediately, don't waste time.
Posts.Title: Please Help!!!

Posts.Content: On Oct 09, 2012 9:19 PM lyss96 wrote: Hi everyone. I tried going on another forum and asking this question but no one answered me....so I found this website and I'm hoping someone will have some insight!   Anways...My mom is 53 years old and she recently had her yearly mammogram and they called her back for more pictures because there was a small area that was suspicious. So she got her other pictures done and the radiologist ended up talking to her and basically just saying "I'm 95% sure this is benign but the other 5%...I'm not sure about. So I want you to get a biopsy." She then talked to the doctor performing the biopsy and she said she felt strongly that this was benign, which is good and then what they were seeing on the mammogram is calcifications. She ended up getting her biopsy last week and she forgot to stop taking advil (you're not supposed to take it 5 days before a procedure like that because it can make you bleed) and ended up bleeding a lot because of not stopping the advil and the doctor doing the procedure knicked an artery or something like that. She ended up having to go to the hospital to stop the bleeding but knock on wood everything's been fine after that. Kind of one of those weird rare things. I'm a constant worrier. Two of her friends actually had the same thing happen to them and their doctors both told them they were 80% sure that it was benign and both ended up being fine. I'm just nervous because everyones different. I worry about everything. And this is no exception. I'm really nervous my mom has breast cancer and something horrible is gonna happen. Basically what I'm trying to get at here is...should I be this worried about it? I understand it's normal to be a little worried...but I'm really a wreck here. I also see that she's a little nervous and that makes me nervous but the only reason she's super nervous is that she has a ton going on (she's getting a divorce). She gets her results tomorrow but the waiting is killing both of us...but once again...am I worrying too much? Hi, has you mom received results of the biopsy. If the results are negative, I wouldn't worry about it.  I too have dense breast tissue and I too like your mom have one spot that is 99.99999% a case of calcification.  I don't worry about it as I am sure that if the spot was that suspicious they would have recommened a biopsy.  I didn't have biopsy done, was told that is not necessary. Again, good luck to you and your mom, please do not worry  - sometimes streess caused by worries can make us ill.  God bless you both. Regards
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer help...

Posts.Content: Dear Jamamma, I had just lost my friend to stage IV BC.  Keep in mind that each case is different, each person reacts differently to treatments and so on.  What works for one person does not necessarily work for another.  I will be thinking of you and your mom. Since I am writing about my friend, in a capsule: Katja had a radical breast removal about two years ago. Doctors were happy and proclaimed her surgery a success. All her follow-up appointments showed no sign of new cancer cells.  However just about five months ago she started experiencing lower back pain.  She went to see the bone doctor and she had an MRI done as well.  How could it happen that MRI does not detect a spine growth is beyond me.  The doctors assured her that her pain is not alarming.  She went to see her gynocologist for a regular follow up. This doctor started suspecting the breast cancer metastasis straiht away and ordered numerous additional tests.  By this time it was too late for my dearest friend.  I suppose her cancer type was an aggressive one and it quickly had spread to her lungs, brain etc,  She is now free of pain and agony and I am glad she is in a better place, but I will always question doctors' wisdom for not concentrating more on heer symptoms and for generally not listening closer to the patients' compaints.  At times doctors dismiss you much too easily. Wish you the bast with you mom.   Aranka
Posts.Title: MY MOTHER NOW HAS STAGE 4 BREAST CANCER

Posts.Content: Dear Jamamma, I had just lost my friend to stage IV BC.  Keep in mind that each case is different, each person reacts differently to treatments and so on.  What works for one person does not necessarily work for another.  I will be thinking of you and your mom. Posts.Title: MY MOTHER NOW HAS STAGE 4 BREAST CANCER
